citation.article-title: Reassignment of Enterobacter dissolvens to Enterobacter cloacae as E. cloacae subspecies dissolvens comb. nov. and emended description of Enterobacter asburiae and Enterobacter kobei.

p.s: The following description is based on data collected on 15 strains in the course of the present study.
General characteristics comply with those described by Brenner et al. [2].
Strains of E. asburiae are gram-negative, oxidase-negative, fermentative, non-pigmented rods with the biochemical properties provided in Table 3.
Tests for use in differentiating E. asburiae from other Enterobacter species are given in Table 4.

All strains produced a Bush class 1 β-lactamase (AmpC), thirteen at a basal level conferring resistance to ampicillin, ampicillin plus clavulanic acid and cefoxitin but not to the rest of antibiotics tested.

One strain hyper-produced AmpC conferring additional resistance to piperacillin, piperacillin plus tazobactam, cefotaxime and ceftazidime, but not to cefepime, gentamicin and trimethoprim plus sulfamethoxazole.
One strain was additionally resistant to trimethoprim plus sulfamethoxazole.
The type strain of the species E. asburiae is ATCC 35953T (CIP 103358T, JCM 6051T).
It was isolated from lochia exsudate of a 22-year-old woman in the USA.
The G+C content of the DNA is 55 mol%.
GenBank accession number of the 16S rDNA is AB004744.
